document_title: Right ventricular myocardial infarction: Causes, signs and treatments
subsection_content:
Diagnosis of right ventricular myocardial infarction (RVMI) includes the following methods.
1. Clinical and paraclinical examination
It is important to consider the diagnosis of right ventricular infarction, especially when an inferior myocardial infarction is present. The typical triad of symptoms observed on examination is hypotension occurring with jugular venous dilation and clear lung auscultation. Left ventricular (LV) function is still contracted.
Tricuspid regurgitation murmur, Kussmaul sign, and paradoxical pulse are signs of significant hemodynamic compromise due to RV ischemia. In some cases, these symptoms are not present upon admission and are not seen until diuretics or nitrates are administered.
2. Two-dimensional echocardiography
This technique can demonstrate right ventricular (RV) dilation with impaired systolic function and RV free wall dyskinesia with paradoxical interventricular septal motion. Doppler examination of specific valvular regurgitation flows can add detailed hemodynamic information and confirm the diagnosis of RV involvement, especially in cases where two-dimensional imaging is technically inadequate. art.
These noninvasive techniques can be used to detect right ventricular dysfunction. Dilated right ventricle with hypokinesis, dyskinesia or dyskinesia of its free wall associated with right ventricular ejection fraction and normal or only mildly impaired left ventricular ejection fraction are signs right ventricular myocardial infarction (RVMI).
3. Check hemodynamics
Hemodynamic testing using right heart catheterization may reveal a disproportionate increase in right-sided filling pressure relative to left-sided filling pressure. Generally accepted criteria for hemodynamically significant RVMI include right atrial pressure (RAP) >10 mmHg, RAP to pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP) ratio >0.8, or RAP < 5mmHg compared to PCWP. However, with concomitant and significant left ventricular (LV) dysfunction, the close relationship between RAP and PCWP is not preserved, although RAP will continue to be elevated.
4. Electrocardiogram (ECG)
This is the first diagnostic test performed in patients with chest pain. If the left ventricle is involved, there may be evidence of ischemia/infarction in inferior leads II, III, and the AVF. Asymmetric ST elevation in leads III>II is prognostic for right ventricular myocardial infarction and requires further investigation.
ST elevation in lead V1 is also highly suspicious for right ventricular myocardial infarction and is even more specific when combined with ST depression in lead V2. In general, the conventional left chest electrocardiogram is a poor indicator of ischemia/infarction at the right cardiac location.
If right-sided dysfunction is suspected, right chest ECG leads have higher sensitivity and specificity, with ST elevation in V4R >1.0mm having 100% sensitivity, 87% specificity and predictive accuracy. guess 92%. Conduction abnormalities such as right bundle branch block, bradycardia, or complete heart block may also be present on the electrocardiogram but may also be nonspecific.
5. Cardiac enzyme test
Cardiac enzymes will increase in the case of right ventricular myocardial infarction, similar to left ventricular myocardial infarction. However, when distinguishing between hemodynamically significant pulmonary embolism (PE) and RVMI, the picture is unclear, as both troponin-I and CK-MB levels may be elevated in a small number of cases of significant PE. .
6. Coronary angiography and ventriculography
This is the gold standard for diagnosing the condition. Coronary angiography usually shows right coronary artery (RCA) occlusion anterior to the right ventricular bifurcation, and more proximal occlusion often suggests more extensive necrosis of the posterior wall and possibly the anterior wall of the RV myocardium.
In patients with left coronary artery predominance, circumflex artery occlusion (LCX) may also be found. Although uncommon, right ventricular myocardial infarction can result from occlusion of the anterior interventricular artery.
Coronary angiography is one of the methods to diagnose right ventricular myocardial infarction.
7. Chest X-ray
This method also has limitations in specificity and diagnostic ability. There may be findings of an enlarged cardiac silhouette, dilated inferior or superior vena cava, and bright lung fields. The presence or absence of pulmonary edema may be helpful in determining the presence or extent of concomitant left ventricular dysfunction or further evaluating the presence of pulmonary embolism (PE).
8. Differential diagnosis
Symptoms of right ventricular myocardial infarction can also be seen in other diseases. Therefore, excluding the following pathologies also contributes to the correct diagnosis of the disease.
Acute aortic dissection; Acute cholecystitis; Acute gastritis; Acute mitral regurgitation; Acute pericarditis; Anxiety disorders; Aortic stenosis; Asthma; Biliary tract disease
